title: Spheroidality / Curvature
intent: Increase adaptability and robustness by replacing rigid, linear structures with flexible, curved, or adaptive ones.

triz_principle.name: Spheroidality / Curvature
triz_principle.definition: Replace linear parts or processes with curved, flexible, or adaptive forms.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We want predictable control, but rigid linear processes break under real-world variability.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Linear plans assume stable inputs; when reality deviates, the system either stalls or collapses.

solution_logic.core_idea: Introduce flexibility, gradation, and feedback instead of rigid straight-line execution.
solution_logic.key_rule: Allow controlled bending instead of forcing straight paths.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: The system adapts continuously, absorbing variability without breaking or stopping.

consulting: rolling-wave planning instead of fixed long-term plans
graduated decision gates instead of binary approvals
adaptive KPIs that adjust to context
software_engineering: progressive validation instead of all-or-nothing checks
backoff strategies instead of fixed retry intervals
graceful degradation instead of hard stops
architecture: elastic scaling instead of fixed capacity
soft constraints with monitoring instead of hard limits
enterprise_sap: adaptive workflows based on risk or volume

use_when: inputs are variable and hard to predict
systems need to operate under fluctuating load
do_not_use_when: regulatory or safety rules forbid flexibility

diagnostic_questions: Where do rigid rules break under real conditions?
Which processes could benefit from gradual adaptation?
How can feedback be used to adjust behavior?

example.before: A fixed approval threshold blocks all transactions above a static limit.
example.after: Dynamic thresholds adjust based on risk, volume, and historical behavior.
